text:
I need to find the intersection between many ranges, or `nothing`/`missing` if there is no such intersection. I figured `intersection` would do this, but it does this instead:
```julia> intersect(1:2, 5:6)
5:4```
Is there another built-in method that will return `nothing` or `missing` in this case?

elements.text: I need to find the intersection between many ranges, or
nothing
missing
if there is no such intersection. I figured
intersection
would do this, but it does this instead:

julia> intersect(1:2, 5:6)
5:4
Is there another built-in method that will return
nothing
or
missing
in this case?

text: I suppose I could  check if the start of the range is greater than the end of the range

elements.text: I suppose I could  check if the start of the range is greater than the end of the range

text: its really odd that its returning 5:4

elements.text: its really odd that its returning 5:4

text: If you first `collect` the ranges, it returns an empty array, as I would expect. Maybe this is necessary for some optimization with ranges instead of more general arrays.

elements.text: If you first
collect
the ranges, it returns an empty array, as I would expect. Maybe this is necessary for some optimization with ranges instead of more general arrays.

text: I think it tries to return a value from the same type or smth, 5:4 is an empty array but a weird one

elements.text: I think it tries to return a value from the same type or smth, 5:4 is an empty array but a weird one

text:
>  5:4 is an empty array
Good point, I can just check `isempty`

Good point, I can just check

text: This may just be a documentation problem

elements.text: This may just be a documentation problem

text:
it looks like a bug to me even if it doesnt affect much it seems to take the first value of the second one like
```intersect(15:20, 35:40)
35:34```

elements.text: it looks like a bug to me even if it doesnt affect much it seems to take the first value of the second one like

text:
Well... there is really no difference apart from printing (and internal representation)
```julia> 2:1 == 3:2 == []
true```

elements.text: Well... there is really no difference apart from printing (and internal representation)

julia> 2:1 == 3:2 == []
true

text: I feel I was just thinking about this from the wrong perspective at first. Returning an empty range (even if it looks weird) is the correct behavior.

elements.text: I feel I was just thinking about this from the wrong perspective at first. Returning an empty range (even if it looks weird) is the correct behavior.

text: Yeah its more of a visual bug which can create confusion. Its not clear to a new user that `5:4` isnt a range that goes from 5 to 4

elements.text: Yeah its more of a visual bug which can create confusion. Its not clear to a new user that
isnt a range that goes from 5 to 4
